topics.content:
Tangent to a Circle 

In the previous section, you have seen that a tangent* to a circle is a line that intersects the circle at only one point.

To understand the existence of the tangent to a circle at a point, let us perform the following activities:
Activity 1 : Take a circular wire and attach a straight wire $A B$ at a point $P$ of the circular wire so that it can rotate about the point $P$ in a plane. Put the system on a table and gently rotate the wire $A B$ about the point $P$ to get different positions of the straight wire [see Fig. 10.3(i)].

In various positions, the wire intersects the circular wire at P and at another point $\mathrm{Q}_{1}$ or $\mathrm{Q}_{2}$ or $\mathrm{Q}_{3}$, etc. In one position, you will see that it will intersect the circle at the point $P$ only (see position $\mathrm{A}^{\prime} \mathrm{B}^{\prime}$ of AB ). This shows that a tangent exists at the point $P$ of the circle. On rotating further, you can observe that in all other positions of $A B$, it will intersect the circle at P and at another point, say $\mathrm{R}_{1}$ or $R_{2}$ or $R_{3}$, etc. So, you can observe that there is only one tangent at a point of the circle.
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Fig. 10.3 (i)

While doing activity above, you must have observed that as the position AB moves towards the position $\mathrm{A}^{\prime} \mathrm{B}^{\prime}$, the common point, say $\mathrm{Q}_{1}$, of the line AB and the circle gradually comes nearer and nearer to the common point $P$. Ultimately, it coincides with the point P in the position $\mathrm{A}^{\prime} \mathrm{B}^{\prime}$ of $\mathrm{A}^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{B}^{\prime \prime}$. Again note, what happens if ' $A B$ ' is rotated rightwards about P ? The common point $\mathrm{R}_{3}$ gradually comes nearer and nearer to P and ultimately coincides with P . So, what we see is:

The tangent to a circle is a special case of the secant, when the two end points of its corresponding chord coincide.

[^0]
[^0]:    *The word 'tangent' comes from the Latin word 'tangere', which means to touch and was introduced by the Danish mathematician Thomas Fineke in 1583.

Activity 2 : On a paper, draw a circle and a secant PQ of the circle. Draw various lines parallel to the secant on both sides of it. You will find that after some steps, the length of the chord cut by the lines will gradually decrease, i.e., the two points of intersection of the line and the circle are coming closer and closer [see Fig. 10.3(ii)]. In one case, it becomes zero on one side of the secant and in another case, it becomes zero on the other side of the secant. See the positions $\mathrm{P}^{\prime} \mathrm{Q}^{\prime}$ and $\mathrm{P}^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{Q}^{\prime \prime}$ of the secant in Fig. 10.3 (ii). These are the tangents to the circle parallel to the given secant PQ. This also helps you to see that there cannot be more than two tangents parallel to a given secant.

Question: Consider a line that touches a circle at only one point. If we have a line segment inside the circle whose endpoints approach the point of tangency, what happens to the relationship between the two lines?
Options:
- The tangent becomes shorter than the segment.
- The tangent and the segment become indistinguishable.
- The tangent becomes perpendicular to the segment.
- The tangent and the segment become parallel.
Correct Answer: The tangent and the segment become indistinguishable.

Question: Imagine a straight road just kissing the edge of a circular park. Now, picture a very short path cutting across the park, getting shorter and shorter until its ends meet at the road's edge. What is the eventual relationship between the road and the path?
Options:
- The road becomes a different curve.
- The road intersects the path at two points.
- The road and the path align perfectly.
- The road and the path become divergent.
Correct Answer: The road and the path align perfectly.

Question: A line touches a circular track at a single point. Now consider a line segment within the circular track whose two endpoints converge to that same point. What statement accurately describes the link between the tangent and the converging line segment?
Options:
- The tangent becomes external to the circle.
- The tangent and the line segment coincide.
- The tangent and the line segment become skew lines.
- The tangent becomes a radius.
Correct Answer: The tangent and the line segment coincide.

Question: Suppose a straight metal bar is pressed against the edge of a round coin at a single point. Now picture an extremely tiny line segment drawn on the coin, shrinking until both its ends meet at the point where the bar touches. What is the final connection between the bar and the tiny segment?
Options:
- The bar becomes curved.
- The bar and the segment both become radii.
- The bar and the segment converge to the same line.
- The bar and the segment become divergent.
Correct Answer: The bar and the segment converge to the same line.

Question: A straight line is tangent to a circular shape. If a chord is drawn within the circle such that its endpoints gradually move closer until they occupy the same point of tangency, how do the tangent and the chord relate to one another in the limit?
Options:
- The tangent becomes the diameter.
- The tangent and the chord effectively become the same line.
- The tangent becomes a secant.
- The tangent and the chord become perpendicular bisectors.
Correct Answer: The tangent and the chord effectively become the same line.

questions.question: Explain why only one tangent can exist at a specific point on a circle.

variations.question: What is the fundamental reason a single point on a circle can have only one line tangent to it?

Because the sum of angles in a circle is always 360 degrees.
Because a tangent's length is always equal to the radius.

questions.question: Compare and contrast the properties of a tangent and a secant line with respect to their intersection points with a circle.
questions.reference_answer: Both tangents and secants are lines that interact with a circle. A secant intersects the circle at two distinct points, forming a chord within the circle. In contrast, a tangent intersects the circle at only one point, known as the point of tangency. A tangent can be considered a limiting case of a secant where the two intersection points coincide.

topics.topic: Number of Tangents from a Point on a Circle
topics.content:
Number of Tangents from a Point on a Circle

To get an idea of the number of tangents from a point on a circle, let us perform the following activity:

Activity 3 : Draw a circle on a paper. Take a point P inside it. Can you draw a tangent to the circle through this point? You will find that all the lines through this point intersect the circle in two points. So, it is not possible to draw any tangent to a circle through a point inside it [see Fig. 10.6 (i)].

Next take a point P on the circle and draw tangents through this point. You have already observed that there is only one tangent to the circle at such a point [see Fig. 10.6 (ii)].

Finally, take a point P outside the circle and try to draw tangents to the circle from this point. What do you observe? You will find that you can draw exactly two tangents to the circle through this point [see Fig. 10.6 (iii)].

We can summarise these facts as follows:
Case 1 : There is no tangent to a circle passing through a point lying inside the circle.
Case 2 : There is one and only one tangent to a circle passing through a point lying on the circle.
Case 3 : There are exactly two tangents to a circle through a point lying outside the circle.

In Fig. 10.6 (iii), $\mathrm{T}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{T}_{2}$ are the points of contact of the tangents $\mathrm{PT}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{PT}_{2}$ respectively.

The length of the segment of the tangent from the external point P and the point of contact with the circle is called the length of the tangent
![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)

Fig. 10.6
from the point P to the circle.

Note that in Fig. 10.6 (iii), $\mathrm{PT}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{PT}_{2}$ are the lengths of the tangents from P to the circle. The lengths $\mathrm{PT}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{PT}_{2}$ have a common property. Can you find this? Measure $\mathrm{PT}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{PT}_{2}$. Are these equal? In fact, this is always so. Let us give a proof of this fact in the following theorem.

Theorem 10.2 : The lengths of tangents drawn from an external point to a circle are equal.
Proof : We are given a circle with centre O, a point P lying outside the circle and two tangents PQ, PR on the circle from P (see Fig. 10.7). We are required to prove that $\mathrm{PQ}=\mathrm{PR}$.

For this, we join OP, OQ and OR. Then $\angle \mathrm{OQP}$ and $\angle$ ORP are right angles, because these are angles between the radii and tangents, and according to Theorem 10.1 they are right angles. Now in right triangles OQP and ORP,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{OQ} & =\mathrm{OR} \\
\mathrm{OP} & =\mathrm{OP}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,
$\Delta \mathrm{OQP} \cong \Delta$ ORP
This gives

$$
\mathrm{PQ}=\mathrm{PR}
$$

questions.question: A tangent PT is drawn to a circle with center O from an external point P. If OP = 10 cm and the radius of the circle is 6 cm, find the length of the tangent PT.

Bisect the line segment connecting the external point and the center.
Draw a circle with the midpoint as center and radius equal to half the distance between the external point and the center.
